desc.size: Medium to large tree, 18 - 30 m tall, trunk diameter 30 cm - 0.6 m. Trunk straight, slender; crown narrow, pyramidal, open with upright branches.

part.partText: thin, relatively smooth on young trees, becoming gray, thick, and deeply fissured into broad, flat-topped ridges.
stout, reddish brown, smooth, becoming dark orange then greenish gray.
reddish brown, 1.5 - 2 cm long, egg-shaped, long-pointed, resinous, fragrant.

alternate, with 3 - 4 cm long, smooth, round leafstalks; dark green above, whitish green or silvery beneath (often stained brown with resin), 8 - 13 cm long, nearly half as wide, egg-shaped to egg-shaped lanceolate, base rounded, tip long and pointed, margins with many low-rounded teeth, thin, firm, lustrous, smooth, young leaves fragrant. Leaves turning yellow to yellowish brown in autumn.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy-bracted catkins; male catkins long-stalked, reddish, 8 - 10 cm long; female catkins long-stalked, loose-flowered, 10 - 13 cm long, slender; wind-pollinated.
a 2-valved capsule; borne in drooping catkins 10 - 15 cm long; short-stalked, 6 - 8 mm long, egg-shaped, seeds light brown with cottony hairs attached; wind-dispersed.

similarSpecies.comments: Populus balsamifera is best distinguished from other Populus species (except P. heterophylla) by having essentially round, not flat, leafstalks. It is distinguished from P. heterophylla by having hairless, often resin-stained leaves with a long tapering tip.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Populus balsamifera is the most widespread native tree species in North America, primarily found in the northern and boreal forest regions. It is typically found in moist habitats, including river floodplains, stream and lake shores, swamps, and moist depressions. In the Chicago Region, it has been found in the dune areas around Lake Michigan, along clay slopes of ravines, in weedy fields, and along railroad right-of-ways. It still occurs as a native in the Chicago Region, but very rarely.

notes.comments: The wood of Populus balsamifera is used for furniture stock, excelsior, boxes, and pulp. Populus species as a whole are subject to many diseases and insect pests, such as canker and tent caterpillars, which often kill the tree or make it unattractive. These risks, in conjunction with a water-hungry root system, have made Populus species less desirable for landscape use.

etymology.comments: Populus is the Latin word for poplar. Balsamifera means balsam-bearing.
